column1: Having poor posture and ergonomics can cause a lot of surprising problems throughout your body, and it doesn't wait until you're elderly to show up. Hopefully a lot of people know this already, but if you're like I was a few months ago, you might think of posture like some people think of diet, sort of like "this won't affect me until I'm older, so I don't need to worry about it yet" (not that that's a good mindset either). Some things that can happen from poor posture are degenerated discs, upper-crossed syndrome, thoracic outlet syndrome (this can result in blot clots and aneurysms, no lie), arthritis, all kinds of pinched nerves, fatigue, and many other painful conditions that can require physical therapy, medications, and even surgery. I couldn't find an academic article about this that fits well, but here's something from the Mayo Clinic about it. To prevent these problems, you should of course have a proper ergonomic setup for work/gaming/whatever you're doing. Sitting on a yoga ball or using a standing desk is a good idea. When driving, try to adjust your seat properly. Even when standing, walking around, and relaxing on your couch try to have your shoulder blades down and together, your shoulders back, and your neck back so that your ears align with your shoulders. Also, this is slightly unrelated, but drinking enough water everyday helps keep your spinal discs healthy. I'm not in the medical field, so anyone who knows more about this is of course welcome to correct me on stuff. I just thought I'd spread the word in case it can help anyone prevent their own problems. I for one didn't know all this before, and now I'm sitting here, only in my 20, with tingly, tired arms and a heating pad on my shoulder because I had bad ergonomics.#Not_suicide

Feminism was, and to an extent remains, a powerful force for cultural change in the United States. The rights, freedoms, and benefits it secured for women and society at large are too many to list, and it is safe to say that life would be significantly worse for everyone without it. However, as with so many popular movements, the widespread adoption of feminism has left it either toothless or antagonistic to progress. I want to interject with a concession: I understand that "feminism" is not a monolith, so this argument is not about subgroups of intersectional feminism or anything. These submovements are still at the cutting edge of social justice, but I will argue that the banner they all fly under is problematic because of its cultural cachet. Throughout the 1800s and 1900s, the major drive of feminism was granting women access to male-dominated spaces. Access to workplaces, pollbooths, and political offices was a specific, ambitious goal with clear markers for success: either women gained access or they did not. In recent decades, however, advancement has become muddled by the movement's partial success. For instance, the metric of income inequality has essentially transformed from "women should earn wages" to "women should earn the same amount as men". The key difference between the two is the ambiguity of the latter, a fun play space for right-wing pundits and centrists alike. When discussing the wage gap, the conversation never focuses on a clearly graspable issue and rather turns into a diatribe about semantics. "The same amount" can mean "the same amount for the same work" or "the same amount controlling for education" or any number of variations that distract from the core issue. Unfortunately, both access and income equality are plagued by punditry debating causality ("women don't want to" is an oft-heard argument against both), but the lack of precise goals in modern feminism only complicates the issue. However, poor mission statements are hardly a reason for a movement to be retired. A few tweaks and edits could reposition modern feminism as a radical and undeniable movement. Intersectional feminists have much more clearly defined goals, for instance. Unfortunately, those feminists who wield disproportionate influence among the broader public, i.e. rich white women, are the ones who define the movement's public goals. Conveniently, famous public feminists like badass Hillary Clinton and boss-babe Sheryl Sandberg push a neoliberal feminism that precludes any meaningful change. And, due to the recuperation of feminism by neoliberal elites, the public perception of feminism is one of a pro-capitalist, status-quo movement. Essentially, the average person views a feminist utopia as "this, but more women". Mainstream feminism's adherence to the status quo extends beyond the economic sector, dipping its fingers into culture, politics, and international relations as well. The early successes of feminism gave the movement an undeniable cultural significance and granted credence to anyone who donned the sacred title. However, because of the mission drift over the past decades, that means the name of feminism has been used to dehumanize trans people, target muslims, and soften the image of oppressive western militarism. Now, this all may seem as petty and semantic as right-wing arguments about the wage gap, but my problem is that the public image of feminism drowns out the smaller movements that have real change in mind. Words have meaning and meaning drifts; the right wing understands this and constantly appropriates left-wing language to pull in centrists. In the same way that socialism was redefined in 1920s Germany to pacify centrists, feminism is being redefined to maintain a neoliberal status quo that preserves the classist structures the first waves of feminism fought to topple. "Feminism" had a good run, but the term has been coopted by the very people it fought against. It's time to abandon it and move on as intersectionalists, anarchists, or, hell, anything else (not humanists, that's been appropriated, too).#Not_suicide

column1: It is rather fashionable today to hate on plastics. Accumulated plastic waste is a major problem and we need to clean up our mess before we end up as George Carlin described it once, "The Earth plus Plastic" and I don't contend that this is not a problem. Waste is a problem. A Big one. But on their own, plastics are one of the greatest inventions we have had in the past 200 years. It is a substance that is strong, chemical stable, resistant to corrosion, generally (not always, but generally) inert to food, lightweight, highly mouldable, cheap, waterproof, non-electrically conducting. I can go on, but at a certain point it gets weird to keep the list going. One of the reasons we have so much plastic waste is that it is actually very good at what it does. You want a substance that can be used to make cheap disposable syringes and improve medical safety and which usually will not react with the medicine? Plastics have you covered. The disposable syringe is arguably the greatest medical breakthrough since the development of antibiotics. That face mask that saved our asses the past one year? Usually Made of melt blown polypropylene. You want cheap, lightweight, sturdy packaging to package perishables over long distance to a place which hit by a famine? Use plastics. When was the last time we have really heard of a famine caused by environmental reasons? Part of the credit goes to plastics, because they have allowed for transportation of food without spoilage across great distances and they don't react easily with the food they are packaging. (there are still some localized famines, but the reasons for them are often unrelated to the technical feasibility of sending food across long distances). You want a cheap strong material to manufacture outer bodies of vehicles thereby reducing vehicle weight and improving fuel efficiency? Look no further than plastics and polymers. Look up. No seriously, look up from your phone or laptop (which are also made of plastic). You'll see at least 10 items without having to move your head that have plastics and would be unaffordable or impractical without them. Even the poorest people and countries in the world now are connected because of cheap electronics which have been made possible in part because of cheap plastics and polymers used to manufacture the bodies and non conducting parts of the circuit boards. (Obviously cheap semiconductor technology is the most important reason). Plastics are all purpose and one of the reasons we have so much waste is because they can be used in a ridiculous number of situations. It is also somewhat unfair to expect people to not use a material so useful and versatile. Because without them we will place tremendous strain on other resources like wood and metal. Now if we are talking about reducing overall consumption, that is a whole other philosophical conversation. From an engineering standpoint, the only sustainable solution to plastic waste is really if we figure out a cheap, effectively limitless source of energy. Recycling is not effective, as anyone from the field would tell you. Most plastics used are not cost effective to recycle due to engineering, process, and economic limitations. An endless energy source would allow us to basically atomize all the waste to their elements or something to that effect. Plastics are not to blame. It has become quite fashionable to trash talk plastics and the companies that manufacture them. One cannot even blame the people. They are an awesome thing. Why shouldn't people use them. They have improved human quality of life by an immeasurable factor. We only need to figure out how to clean up our mess. We have the technical know how. Just need an energy source that can sustain the cleanup process.#Not_suicide

I know that earth is not truly "overpopulated" with people, but even if all current resources were distributed equally, we are still going to see a huge decrease in overall available resources (food, arable land, drinkable water etc) due to climate change induced collapse. We don't have the resources to provide 8 billion + people with the current standard of living that we experience in the first world (if you're middle class or richer). So if you throw away all notions of "the economy needs to keep growing" (because it can't), the world's population does need to decrease, or we need to lower the living standards and consumption for the first world drastically. Or both. The latter will never happen voluntarily, and we want to do everything possible to mitigate climate change so that we aren't forced to drop our living standards. Very few women truly want to have 5+ children. We can see that anytime that women gain more control over their own fertility in a society, they voluntarily choose to have fewer children, or no children at all. So why don't more people talk about how feminism and bodily autonomy for women could result in the world population decreasing naturally? The birth rates in the first world are below replacement rate as it is. In my generation (23) and Gen Z, the majority of us know that the climate is only going to get worse, and acknowledge that any children born from now on will almost certainly live very difficult lives. As long as we aren't forced to have children, I doubt many of us will. If the birth rates drop even further, the rich/powerful countries will just increase immigration rates if they want to hold onto the idea of neverending capitalist growth for longer. Things will be terrible for elderly people in poorer countries with an inverted population pyramid, but they would likely be even worse off in any of the other possible collapse related outcomes. Of all potential outcomes for climate change related collapse, in my opinion this situation would have the least war and conflict.#Not_suicide

column1: People are really convinced in the West that technology can fix climate issues, and have been using that as an excuse to kick the can down the road and avoid actually changing anything about our society or economy. I've been reading about "Solar Radiation Management" which entails shooting phosphates into the stratosphere to deflect solar radiation and prevent warming. People in the actual environmental movement are endorsing this stuff, especially in the West, when the risks are astronomically higher than the potential reward. The idea is basically to emulate the eruption of volcanos which tend to create a layer of permanent cloud cover that blocks sunlight. However, if you look at what happens during these eruptions, rain patterns change, crops die, and as always, the global south is disproportionately affected. Not to mention the fact that the second we stop doing it, we get hit with a wall of all of that pent up heat. Beyond that, we just don't know what could happen with this tech – the only way to test the global effects are to just do it.
